DataElement.preferredName: Local Pathology Review Hematoxylin and Eosin Staining Method Slide Device Component Biospecimen Pre-analytical Variables Program Eligibility Determination Histologic Confirmation Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: An indication of whether the local pathology review of the H&E slide derived from QC FFPE tumor tissue confirmed the histological type eligible for the study.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Local Pathology Review Hematoxylin and Eosin Staining Method Slide Device Component Biospecimen Pre-analytical Variables Program Eligibility Determination Histologic Confirmation
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Microscopic examination of tissue specimen(s) by a pathologist in the local institution where a patient had a procedure performed, using local standardized methods and criteria._Hematoxylin-and-eosin, or H&E, is a routine staining procedure of tissue sections. This staining method uses two separate dyes, one staining the nucleus and the other staining the cytoplasm and connective tissue. Hematoxylin is a dark purplish dye that stains the chromatin (nuclear material) within the nucleus. Eosin is an orangish-pink to red dye that stains the cytoplasmic material including connective tissue and collagen._A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study._A program designed to systematically investigate the effects of individual pre-analytical factors on the molecular profiles of biospecimens. The results of this study will be used to develop evidence-based protocols and best practices for optimal collection, processing, and storage of biospecimens._Criteria to determine eligibility of patients for medical care programs and services._Pertaining to the combined microscopic physical features of cells and their surrounding extracellular environment in tissues._Having been established or verified.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Microscopic examination of tissue specimen(s) by a pathologist in the local institution where a patient had a procedure performed, using local standardized methods and criteria.

Concepts.definition: Microscopic examination of tissue specimen(s) by a pathologist in the local institution where a patient had a procedure performed, using local standardized methods and criteria.

Property.preferredName: Hematoxylin and Eosin Staining Method Slide Device Component Biospecimen Pre-analytical Variables Program Eligibility Determination Histologic Confirmation
Property.preferredDefinition: Hematoxylin-and-eosin, or H&E, is a routine staining procedure of tissue sections. This staining method uses two separate dyes, one staining the nucleus and the other staining the cytoplasm and connective tissue. Hematoxylin is a dark purplish dye that stains the chromatin (nuclear material) within the nucleus. Eosin is an orangish-pink to red dye that stains the cytoplasmic material including connective tissue and collagen.:A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study.:A program designed to systematically investigate the effects of individual pre-analytical factors on the molecular profiles of biospecimens. The results of this study will be used to develop evidence-based protocols and best practices for optimal collection, processing, and storage of biospecimens.:Criteria to determine eligibility of patients for medical care programs and services.:Pertaining to the combined microscopic physical features of cells and their surrounding extracellular environment in tissues.:Having been established or verified.

Concepts.definition: Hematoxylin-and-eosin, or H&E, is a routine staining procedure of tissue sections. This staining method uses two separate dyes, one staining the nucleus and the other staining the cytoplasm and connective tissue. Hematoxylin is a dark purplish dye that stains the chromatin (nuclear material) within the nucleus. Eosin is an orangish-pink to red dye that stains the cytoplasmic material including connective tissue and collagen.
A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study.

A program designed to systematically investigate the effects of individual pre-analytical factors on the molecular profiles of biospecimens. The results of this study will be used to develop evidence-based protocols and best practices for optimal collection, processing, and storage of biospecimens.
The act of determining if a subject is suitable for enrollment in a study according specific protocol criteria and procedures.
Pertaining to the combined microscopic physical features of cells and their surrounding extracellular environment in tissues.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).
